pages_reviewed.reason: Systematic Greek character corruption (ayνοία, ἀληθεία unreadable), umlaut failures (phänomenon→phiinomen), character swallowing (oftovering→of covering). Real OCR errors.

pages_reviewed.reason: CONFIRMED_BAD: 'ithavelostitselfand', 'habenkann' (space merges). FALSE_POSITIVE: 'Jemeinigkeit', 'gieichgiiltigkeit' (should be Gleichgültigkeit but is German concept of 'indifference'), 'verlieren' are legitimate German terms.

pages_reviewed.reason: CONFIRMED_BAD: 'aufgedcckt' (double-c error for aufgedeckt), space merging, 'constitu' and 'senting' fragments. FALSE_POSITIVE: 'verhält' is correct German verb form (relates/behaves), core Heideggerian term.

key_findings: Many German philosophical terms incorrectly classified as OCR errors: Dasein, Weltlichkeit, Seinsverhältnis, Jemeinigkeit, eigensten, zeitigen, Nachsicht, schuld, etc.
Real OCR errors predominantly: space-removal/merging, footnote embedding, Greek/Latin character corruption, truncations
Pages 160, 161, 163, 194, 205, 216 appear to have GOOD OCR quality but were incorrectly flagged
Highest corruption: page 125 (23.5%), page 126 (18.2%), page 243 (18.8% - Latin fable)
Critical corruption in foundational texts: Parmenides quotations (p257), Cura fable (p243), title error (p267)
recommendations: Update ground truth classifier to recognize common German philosophical terms
Create allowlist for Heideggerian vocabulary: Dasein, Sein, Zuhandenheit, Vorhandenheit, Weltlichkeit, Seinsverhältnis, etc.
Focus re-OCR efforts on pages with CONFIRMED_BAD classification and error rates >15%
Pages with FALSE_POSITIVE classification should be moved to ACCEPTABLE quality tier
Pay special attention to Greek and Latin quotations - these are citation-critical
